Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SHF: Three-Dimensional Electronics Integration Facilitated by Molecular Assembly

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
For the production of electronic devices like computers and smart phones, conventional lithographic techniques provide error-free circuits, but their development in critical directions is limited by their inherently two-dimensional nature. On the other hand, biological structures are inherently three-dimensional, however their error-prone self-assembly procedures require biological systems to utilize error-tolerant architectures. This project will mimic biology using materials that self-assemble by molecular recognition for programmed fabrication of electronic devices. Such fabrication methods could potentially generate revolutionary technology in information processing, computer, and communications applications. This research could increase the speed and energy efficiency of some computations and decrease the cost of their production. The project will provide interdisciplinary research training at the graduate, undergraduate, and postdoc levels. Participation by under-represented groups will be pursued and encouraged at all levels including through Project SEED for high school students.

By applying techniques of affinity peptide-based assembly and structural DNA nanotechnology to create bioinspired materials with macro-scale dimensions and nano- scale feature resolution, this project will generate unique, electronically-active, materials with integral networks that are expected to display interesting non-linear behaviors. These materials have potential for use in novel three-dimensionally integrated circuits with extremely-high connectivity that are predicted to display useful electrical behaviors and will be developed for computation, communications, signal processing, and control applications.

ProgramReference.Text: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project advanced basic research in computational science by exploring new materials and strategies for Reservoir Computing - an unconventional, neuromorphic approach to information processing. Conventional lithographic fabrication techniques provide error-free electronic circuits, but their development in critical directions is limited by their inherently two-dimensional nature. On the other hand, biological structures are inherently 3D, however their error-prone fabrication by self-assembly requires error-tolerant, network architectures. We have used random assembly of composite materials to create bioinspired materials with macro-scale dimensions and nano-scale features. We demonstrated self-assembly of memristive switching networks formed from nanowires and nanoparticles composed of silver, silver sulfide, tungsten oxide, zinc oxide, and carbon nanomaterials.  This project has generated unique, electronically-active, materials with integral memristive networks that have been shown to display interesting non-linear electronic behaviors. We successfully used these materials to map a set of computational problems into a higher dimensional space in which they were easy to solve using simple linear regression. These materials have potential for use in novel three-dimensionally integrated circuits with extremely-high connectivity that should be useful for specific applications in computation, communications, signal processing, and control applications. 

Broader Impacts: This project has provide foundational knowledge for implementing unconventional hardware for information processing devices. Future impacts could include advances in artificial intelligence especially regarding real-time decision making and control involving complex, high-dimensional data streams. Significant graduate and post-graduate research training opportunities were realized during the execution of this project, providing valuable experience for the next generation of scientific researchers. 


Last Modified: 01/13/2020
Modified by: Thom Labean
